message.content:
cs.LO, cs.GT, cs.AI, cs.DS, cs.PL

This paper deals with two-player games played over finite state spaces, which are commonly studied in the field of logic and automata theory. The paper introduces equivalences and metrics for these game structures, which are fundamental notions in the study of transition systems and formal verification. Therefore, the most likely sub-category is cs.LO (Logic in Computer Science). 

The paper also discusses the use of probability distributions in these games, which is a topic commonly studied in game theory and decision theory. This suggests that cs.GT (Computer Science and Game Theory) is another likely sub-category. 

The paper also mentions the use of the quantitative mu-calculus to express goals in these games, which is a formal language commonly used in formal verification and model checking. This suggests that cs.AI (Artificial Intelligence) and cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms) are also likely sub-categories. 

Finally, the paper discusses the generalization of bisimulation and simulation to these game structures, which are concepts commonly studied in the field of programming languages and semantics. This suggests that cs.PL (Programming Languages) is another likely sub-category.
